Award.AwardTitle: The Emergence Of Modern Human Behavior

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Humanity has been associated with high levels of extinctions among competing species, not only in the modern world of industrialized agriculture but even from the first appearance of our species, Homo sapiens, during the Pleistocene Epoch. In fact, one of the fundamental questions in human evolution is, what was the nature of the interaction between the earliest modern humans from Africa and their Eurasian competitors, the Neanderthals, that resulted in the latter's extinction 30,000 years ago? Physical anthropology shows that the modern human advantage was not physical prowess. Current archaeological research thus focuses on the modern human landscape adaptation, i.e., how they strategized use of resources in time and space (how they hunted animals, foraged for plants, and relied on other humans for security), as potentially distinct from their evolutionary cousins. Testing competing hypotheses of the contrast between Neanderthal and modern human landscape adaptations requires high-resolution archaeological data from the excavation of sites with the potential to discriminate what activities the occupants were pursuing in that given site.

The multidisciplinary team created by Dr. Gilbert Tostevin & Dr. Gilliane Monnier, both of the University of Minnesota, along with colleagues in the Czech Republic, Germany, and Israel, will investigate one such site, Tvaro ná-Za kolou in the Czech Republic, that contains artifacts of the archaeological culture most likely representing the earliest modern human penetration into Neanderthal-occupied Europe. This culture, the Bohunician, appears to have spread into Central Europe from the Near East but did not penetrate further west than Bohemia, nor further east than western Ukraine. The limited success of the Bohunician adaptation over the Neanderthals stands in contrast to the Aurignacian, the modern human culture that spread 5,000 years later across all of Europe and is associated with the extinction of the Neanderthals. The project at Tvaro ná-Za kolou is designed to produce the highest resolution of data on the Bohunician landscape adaptation to date, thereby advancing archaeologists' ability to contrast the Bohunician, Aurignacian, and Neanderthal landscape adaptations. Not only will the project help discriminate what made modern humans' Ice Age ancestors so successful, it will also provide field and laboratory training for US, Czech, and other nations' graduate students in the teams innovative microarchaeological and 3D artifact modeling techniques, the latter providing the first publicly-accessible digital collection of artifacts from the entirety of a site of this age.

The aim of this project is the high-resolution excavation, analysis, and dating of the Tvaro ná-Za kolou site. By reconstructing stone tool production at the site in relation to the use of organic artifacts that did not preserve (but that can be detected chemically in the site's sediment), the team will establish a new method for determining how a site's function within the population's landscape adaptation affects the artifactual content of the site. When applied to other sites in the region, this approach will transform archaeologists' ability to understand adaptive differences between modern humans and Neanderthals in this, and other, regions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Emergence Of Modern Human Behavior

One of the fundamental questions in human evolution is, what was the nature of the interaction between the earliest modern humans from Africa and their Eurasian competitors, the Neanderthals, that resulted in the latter’s extinction 30,000 years ago? Physical anthropology shows that the modern human advantage was not our physical prowess, since we were weaker than most of our contemporaries. Current archaeological research focuses on the modern human landscape adaptation, i.e., how we strategized our use of resources in time and space (how we hunted animals, foraged for plants, and relied on other humans for security). Testing competing hypotheses of the contrast between Neanderthal and modern human landscape adaptations requires high-resolution archaeological data from the excavation of sites with the potential to discriminate what activities the occupants were pursuing in that given site.

 

The multidisciplinary team created by Dr. Gilbert Tostevin & Dr. Gilliane Monnier, both of the University of Minnesota, along with colleagues in the Czech Republic, Germany, and Israel, investigated one such site, Tvaro?ná-Za školou or Tvaro?ná X in the Czech Republic, which contains artifacts of the archaeological culture most likely representing the earliest modern human penetration into Neanderthal-occupied Europe. This archaeological culture, the Bohunician, appears to have spread into Central Europe from the Near East but did not penetrate further west than Bohemia, nor further east than western Ukraine. The limited success of the Bohunician adaptation over the Neanderthals stands in contrast to the Aurignacian, the modern human culture that spread 5,000 years later across all of Europe and is associated with the extinction of the Neanderthals. The project at Tvaro?ná X was designed to retrieve the highest possible resolution of data on the Bohunician landscape adaptation to date, thereby advancing archaeologists’ ability to contrast the Bohunician, Aurignacian, and Neanderthal landscape adaptations. 

 

The intellectual merit of the project is evident in its design and the example it provides for future research into this time period. Much of the previous inability to contrast the modern human against the Neanderthal landscape adaptation has been that all of the Bohunician and Aurignacian sites in the Middle Danube Basin of Central Europe are open-air sites formed in paleosols, i.e., relict buried soils that tend not to preserve even hard organic materials such as bones. This makes it difficult to determine a site’s function and thus the modern human vs. Neanderthal use of the landscape. At Tvaro?ná X, our team endeavored to solve this problem by applying microarchaeology to test for the original presence vs. absence of now-invisible behaviors that would inform on site function, such as butchery, hearth creation, or plant processing.

 

In order to understand the Bohunician landscape adaptations, a suite of macroarchaeological techniques were also applied. Through a comparison of how stone tools of different chert & flint types were produced on site in sequential, connected events (when stone tools can be refit together) vs. deposited more individually during non-sequential occupations, the team was able to demonstrate a new site function for Tvaro?ná X previously unknown in Bohunician sites. Unlike the raw material workshops and residential camps of previous sites, Tvaro?ná X’s occupation was non-continuous, with short but frequent visitations. This site was thus a staging area, rather than an occupational camp, for hunters and foragers returning to the Brno Basin from long-distance trips ranging from 10 km to the north (into the Moravian Karst) to as far as 200 km to the southeast, into northwestern Hungary. This model of a ‘staging area’ site is a first for the Bohunician. Additionally, our radiocarbon dates place the site firmly within the known Bohunician time range, with occupations spanning from 44,000 to 41,000 years ago.

 

The broader impacts of the project are significant. It provided field and laboratory training for US, Czech, French, Italian, Irish, and Slovakian graduate and undergraduate students. The students gained an appreciation for cultural diversity through living and working within such an international team. They learned scientific methods used in the project’s innovative microarchaeological and 3D artifact modeling techniques, the latter providing the first publicly-accessible digital research-grade collection of stone tool artifacts from an entire Bohunician site. The 3D collection is currently freely available on-line to the public and scientific researchers at the Data Repository of the University of Minnesota (at z.umn.edu/TvaroznaX). Eight US students received significant research experience and training during the project; four of the graduate students were women (three of whom now have jobs in scientific fields). Three undergraduate student theses were produced through the project (all of them women). The project members also engaged in the wider education in archaeological science of the public through open-visitation days for villagers of Tvaro?ná, Czech Republic.
